claim: The Product Backlog must be a single, prioritized source of truth for all work—features, bugs, technical debt. Multiple backlogs or unprioritized lists cause misaligned effort and wasted resources.
rationale: Without a single ordered list, teams lack clarity on what matters most. Work gets done based on who shouts loudest rather than what delivers value. The backlog's power lies in forcing explicit prioritization decisions.

claim: Refine backlog items just-in-time: top items need detail and estimates, lower items stay high-level. Over-specifying distant items wastes effort on requirements that will change.
rationale: Detailed specifications for low-priority items become obsolete before development. Progressive elaboration focuses effort on imminent work while maintaining strategic visibility of future possibilities.

claim: Use WSJF (Weighted Shortest Job First): divide Cost of Delay by job duration. High-value, low-effort items should be tackled first to maximize economic throughput.
rationale: WSJF ensures items with highest value-to-effort ratio rise to top. It accounts for time criticality and opportunity cost, not just perceived importance, optimizing economic return on development capacity.

claim: Slice stories vertically: each slice delivers end-to-end value across all system layers. Horizontal slices (just UI, just backend) delay value delivery and hide integration risks.
rationale: Vertical slices are independently shippable and testable. They enable faster feedback, reduce integration surprises, and ensure every sprint delivers user-facing value rather than incomplete components.

claim: Allocate 10-30% of sprint capacity explicitly to technical debt and bugs. Neglecting these for feature work creates compounding slowdown and system fragility over time.
rationale: Technical debt increases future development cost exponentially. Explicit allocation prevents the 'future me will fix it' trap and ensures product remains maintainable and performant long-term.

claim: Every backlog item needs a clear 'why'—the problem it solves, user it helps, and measurable outcome expected. Items without value statements lead to feature factories building unwanted things.
rationale: Without explicit value articulation, teams build what was requested rather than what solves problems. The 'why' provides context for implementation decisions and enables outcome measurement.

claim: Outcome-driven backlogs organize around desired results ('increase conversion by 10%'), not features. Features become hypotheses for achieving outcomes, encouraging experimentation over specification.
rationale: Feature-driven backlogs risk building many things with unclear impact. Outcome framing ensures development effort ties directly to measurable business value and empowers teams to find the best solutions.

claim: The 'wish list' trap: backlog becomes unprioritized dumping ground where everything is important. Without rigorous ordering, teams lack direction and work on low-value tasks.
rationale: When everything is priority 1, nothing is truly prioritized. Teams become overwhelmed, stakeholders frustrated, and development effort fragments across too many initiatives to achieve meaningful progress.

claim: The 'static list' trap: backlog created once and rarely updated becomes irrelevant. Teams work on features that no longer matter while missing new market opportunities.
rationale: Markets, customers, and strategies change constantly. A backlog that doesn't evolve with new information leads to wasted effort on outdated priorities and inability to respond to emerging needs.

claim: HiPPO prioritization: allowing the Highest Paid Person's Opinion to dictate backlog order without objective analysis leads to biased decisions and ignored customer needs.
rationale: Senior stakeholders have valuable perspective but also blind spots and pet projects. Without data-driven prioritization frameworks, backlogs reflect organizational politics rather than customer value.

claim: Ignoring technical debt for features creates compounding slowdown. Codebases become harder to work with, bugs increase, developers burn out, and feature delivery actually slows.
rationale: Technical debt is invisible to stakeholders but real to engineers. Continuous deferral creates a 'debt spiral' where maintenance consumes increasing capacity, eventually crippling innovation ability.

claim: Definition of Ready checklist: items must be clear, testable (acceptance criteria), estimated, small enough for one sprint, and have dependencies resolved before entering development.
rationale: Pulling unclear items into sprints causes mid-sprint confusion, delays, and incomplete work. A clear readiness gate ensures smooth flow and predictable delivery.

claim: Hierarchical backlog structure: Themes (strategic) → Epics (initiatives) → Features (capabilities) → User Stories (sprint-sized). This provides traceability from strategy to execution.
rationale: Flat backlogs lose strategic context. Hierarchical structure ensures every task traces to business goals, enables planning at multiple levels, and maintains alignment across large organizations.

claim: User Story Mapping: visualize user journey horizontally, place stories vertically by priority beneath each step. Draw horizontal lines to define releases that deliver end-to-end value.
rationale: Story mapping reveals gaps in user journeys and prevents building features in isolation. It ensures each release delivers complete experiences rather than disconnected functionality.

claim: High average backlog item age indicates stagnation. Items sitting untouched for 6+ months are likely obsolete—prune them or reprioritize to keep the backlog lean and relevant.
rationale: Old items lose context, requirements drift, and the backlog becomes cluttered with irrelevant work. Regular pruning ensures focus on current priorities and reduces cognitive load.

claim: Spotify's Squad model decentralizes backlogs: each autonomous squad owns its backlog aligned to its mission, while Tribes provide strategic coordination without dictating priorities.
rationale: Decentralized ownership enables speed and accountability. Squads make prioritization decisions closest to execution while strategic alignment flows through shared missions rather than hierarchical control.

claim: Google's OKR framework cascades objectives to backlog prioritization: every backlog item must contribute to a measurable Key Result, creating clear strategic filter for what gets built.
rationale: OKRs prevent backlog 'wish list' syndrome by requiring every item to justify its contribution to measurable outcomes. Items that don't move KRs get deprioritized regardless of stakeholder enthusiasm.
